Award.AwardTitle: Bubbles for Separating Particles from Suspensions: Thin Films and Curved Channels

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Small particles find a wide range of applications, from drug delivery and sensing to serving as fillers for altering the properties of materials. The particle size and the size distribution are often critical and so it is common to seek to separate particles by size from a mixture of particles with various sizes. As one example is blood, where it is often desired to separate the large white blood cells from the somewhat smaller flexible red blood cells from the even smaller platelets. It remains a challenge to perform such separations in many circumstances. Here the investigators demonstrate a new idea for accomplishing such particle-size separations by flowing a long gas bubble in a cylindrical tube filled with a suspension. The motion of the bubble is a well-understood fluid dynamics problem that we exploit in a new way. In particular, we show that the speed of the bubble selects a critical size of smaller particles that can flow past the bubble while larger particles remain in front of the bubble. Thus, the bubble acts as a filter for particles. Several variants of this problem are studied for different channel geometries and the efficiency of the new separation process will be characterized.

Technologies are needed to separate particles by size from a suspension, and it remains a challenge to separate particles in the micron and sub-micron range. A long bubble translating in a tube is separated from the boundaries by a thin liquid film, whose thickness varies with flow speed, as is well known in the fluid mechanics literature. Here this thin film is shown to act as a speed-dependent filter for separating particles by size from a suspension. Thus, this configuration is exploited to (1) study the efficiency of separation by size for a bubble translating through a horizontal channel filled with a bidisperse suspension, (2) study the thin films formed when one or more bubbles translates in curved channels, and (3) study the separation efficiency of bubbles translating through suspension-filled curved channels and vertical channels, the latter potentially allowing the most effective continuous flow process for such separations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied the motion of a long bubble translating in a tube from the perspective of understanding this configuration as a speed-dependent filter for separating particles by size from a suspension.  The premise of the idea is that when a bubble translates through the liquid it is separated from the boundaries by a thin film, whose thickness varies with flow speed, which is a topic that is otherwise well known in the fluid mechanics literature. We considered a bubble translating through a horizontal channel filled with a bidisperse suspension and demonstrated using experiments the efficiency of particle separation by size; the results were explained quantitatively using mathematical modeling. Also, we studied the manner in which the thin film around the bubble adjusts itself when the bubble speed is time dependent. In addition, we investigated the motion of bubbles in vertical tubes including the effect of an external upward or downward flow. The latter topic included experiments, mathematical modeling, and full numerical simulations and we discovered that the dynamics displayed an unexpected nonuniqueness, i.e., that two different bubble shapes and speeds were possible for otherwise similar external flow conditions. Finally, our focus on fluid mechanics problems with thin viscous films led us to consider the drainage of a thin film near an edge of a vertical plate. We discovered a new form of self-similar scaling: a problem with three independent variables is shown, by an appropriate change of variables, to convert to a problem with only one independent variable and the associated scalings rationalize all of the experimental observations. Finally, we investigated a second thin film problem by considering gravitational drainage in geometries that cause convergence of the flow. Experiments and mathematical modeling were developed together, with very good agreement between the two. Overall, our studies advanced fluid mechanics understanding of particulate flows involving thin viscous films.
